facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 16, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1403 of 1953.

facts.text: Arising out of the Judgment and order dated August 6, 1953, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Meerut in Criminal Appeal No. 225 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Judgment and order dated August 6, 1953, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Meerut in Criminal Appeal No. 225 of 1953. J. Umrigar and K. L. Mehta, for the appellant. C. Mathur, C. P. Lal and G. N. Dikshit, for the respondent. 1959. April 23.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered on April 23, 1959 by IMAM, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. April 23. The Judgment of-the Court was delivered by IMAM, J.-The appellant was companyvicted under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act and under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to one years rigorous imprisonment on each companynt.

facts.text: Appellant was convicted under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act and under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act and under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to one years rigorous imprisonment on each companynt. The sentences were made to run companycurrently.

The appellant was employed at that time as a clerk in the office of the District Relief and Rehabilitation Office, Meerut.

facts.text: Appellant was employed as a clerk in the office of the District Relief and Rehabilitation Office, Meerut.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was employed at that time as a clerk in the office of the District Relief and Rehabilitation Office, Meerut. The aforesaid sum of money was accepted by the appellant as bribe with a view to getting a house allotted to Malekchand. There can be numberquestion that, on the facts found, the appellant was guilty both under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act and under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant accepted the Rs. 20 as bribe to get a house allotted to Malekchand.

facts.text: Investigation was conducted by a police officer below the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police.

anchor.surface_text: The first point taken was that the investigation had taken place by a police officer below the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police. Consequently, the investigation had taken place in companytravention of the provisions of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

facts.text: This point was taken before the Additional Sessions Judge who heard the appeal against conviction.

anchor.surface_text: This point was taken before the Additional Sessions Judge who had heard the appeal of the appellant against his companyviction. The Additional Sessions Judge referred to a decision of the Calcutta High Court which supported the submission made on behalf of the appellant.

facts.text: Case committed to Court of Session before Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 came into force.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, however, that the case had been companymitted to the Court of Session before the Criminal Law  Amendment  Act, 1952, came into force. Under s. 10 of this Act all cases pending before the Court of a Magistrate were transferred to the Court of a Special Judge.

facts.text: Courts below found that Rs.20 was paid by Malekchand to appellant on demand to secure house allotment.

anchor.surface_text: There is ample evidence on behalf of the prosecution to the companyclusion that the sum of Rs. 20 was paid by Malekchand to the applicant on his demand in order to secure the allotment of a house. There does number appear any satisfactory reason why Malekchand should have paid Rs. 20 to the applicant to procure wheat for him.

facts.text: Appellant's defence that Rs.20 taken from Malekchand to purchase wheat was disbelieved.

arguments.claim: On the facts found by the courts below, the appellant was guilty both under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act and under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: On the facts found by the courts below the appellant accepted Rs. 20/- as illegal gratification from one Malekchand who had applied for allotment of a house. The appellant was employed at that time as a clerk in the office of the District Relief and Rehabilitation Office, Meerut. The aforesaid sum of money was accepted by the appellant as bribe with a view to getting a house allotted to Malekchand. precedents.citation: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi  1

anchor.surface_text: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi  1  does number support the submission made by Mr. Umrigar on behalf of the appellant. He, however, referred to a passage in the aforesaid cited decision at page 1164 to the effect that where a breach of a mandatory provision is brought to the knowledge of the companyrt at a sufficiently early stage, the companyrt, while number declining companynizance, would have to take the necessary steps to get the illegality cured and the defect rectified by ordering such investigation as the circumstances of the case may call for. It has number been shown to our satisfaction that the attention of the trial companyrt was drawn at an early stage to any breach of the provisions of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

precedents.case_name: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Investigation in contravention of Prevention of Corruption Act by officer below DSP rank does not vitiate conviction unless breach brought to court's knowledge at sufficiently early stage
precedents.cited_holding: where a breach of a mandatory provision is brought to the knowledge of the court at a sufficiently early stage, the court, while not declining cognizance, would have to take the necessary steps to get the illegality cured and the defect rectified by ordering such investigation as the circumstances of the case may call for

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Asgarali Nazarali Singaporewalla v. The .State 1 , this Court observed The cases which were pending before the companyrts of sessions did number require to be so transferred because they would be tried by the procedure obtaining in the companyrts of sessions and numberhing further required to be done. It seems clear to us, therefore, that the Assistant Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case as the same had been pending in the companyrt of Session when the Act came into force.

precedents.case_name: Asgarali Nazarali Singaporewalla v. The State
precedents.cited_proposition: Cases pending before courts of sessions at commencement of Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952 did not require transfer to Special Judge
precedents.cited_holding: The cases which were pending before the courts of sessions did not require to be so transferred because they would be tried by the procedure obtaining in the courts of sessions and nothing further required to be done
